radioGroup.prompt: In the “wh”-relative clauses which are similar to content questions, can a relative marker also occur in the complementizer position?
radioGroup.radio: No, only the “wh”-word meaning ‘who’ or ‘which’ occurs in this type of relative clause
Yes, the “wh”-word meaning ‘who’ or ‘which’ and the relative marker(s) are required to both be present in this type of relative clause
Yes, a relative marker may optionally co-occur along with the “wh”-word meaning ‘who’ or ‘which’ in this type of relative clause

form.instruction: In the lexicon, add the feature relative to the “wh”-words which can be used in relative clauses. If your language has animacy agreement between the head noun and the wh-relative word (like English “who” versus “which”), also add the feature animate to the animate forms and add the feature -animate to the inanimate forms.

radioGroup.prompt: Are the relative markers written as an independent word?
radioGroup.radio: Yes, they are all independent words
Some are written as independent words, but some attach to another word at the edge of the relative clause
No, they are all clitics which attach to another word at the edge of the relative clause

radioGroup.prompt: Where does the relative marker clitic attach to the rest of the relative clause?
radioGroup.radio: As a proclitic which attaches to the beginning of the first word in the sentence part of the relative clause
As an enclitic which attaches to the end of the last word in the sentence part of the relative clause
Both a proclitic and an enclitic surround the sentence part of the relative clause

form.instruction: In the lexicon, add the feature relative_prefix to these clitics.
In the lexicon, add the feature relative_suffix to these clitics.
In the lexicon, add the feature relative_prefix to the proclitics and add relative_suffix to the enclitics.
form.prompt: Key the independent words which are used to mark relative clauses here:
form.instruction: In the lexicon, the relative markers which are independent words need the features makeC relative. This will assure the category C so they will occur in the complementizer position and allow their appearance only in a relative clause. Any markers which can occur as the complementizer in a CP which is a complement of a verb, like ‘that’ in English, need to have two separate entries in the lexicon. Mark the second entry with the feature makeC and it will default to not being allowed in relative clauses. (If the same marker can also be used in questions, a third entry is needed with the features makeC question.)

form.introduction: Some languages also allow one of the above structures to occur by itself as a nominal phrase without a head noun to modify, usually called “headless” relative clauses. For example, Julie brought [the food that we ate today] has a full relative clause in the object position, while Julie brought [what we ate today] has a headless relative clause as the object.

radioGroup.prompt: Does your language allow headless relative clauses?
radioGroup.radio: No, a head noun is required
Yes, a head noun may be missing
